content:
PropertyGrid Class

Definition

Provides a user interface for browsing the properties of an object.

In this Article

[System.ComponentModel.Designer("System.Windows.Forms.Design.PropertyGridDesigner, System.Design, Version=4.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b03f5f7f11d50a3a")]
[System.Runtime.InteropServices.ClassInterface(System.Runtime.InteropServices.ClassInterfaceType.AutoDispatch)]
[System.Runtime.InteropServices.ComVisible(true)]
public class PropertyGrid : System.Windows.Forms.ContainerControl, System.Windows.Forms.ComponentModel.Com2Interop.IComPropertyBrowser

Remarks

To use the property grid, you create a new instance of the PropertyGrid class on a parent control and set SelectedObject to the object to display the properties for.

The information displayed in the grid is a snapshot of the properties at the time the object is assigned. If a property value of the object specified by the SelectedObject is changed in code at run time, the new value is not displayed until an action is taken in the grid that causes the grid to refresh.

The property tabs within the property grid appear as buttons on the toolbar at the top of the PropertyGrid, and can vary in scope as defined in the PropertyTabScope.

You can use the LargeButtons property to display large buttons instead of the default smaller ones. Large buttons are 32-by-32 pixels rather than the standard 16-by-16 pixels. The large and small buttons and the property list expander icons (the plus or minus icons) are resized according to the system DPI setting when the app.config file contains the following entry: 

<appSettings>  
  <add key="EnableWindowsFormsHighDpiAutoResizing" value="true" />  
</appSettings>

The PropertyGrid control is not initially presented in the toolbox in the development environment. You can add a property grid to the toolbox, which enables you to drag a PropertyGrid onto your form. You can also define an instance of PropertyGrid by adding the appropriate code in your source code.

All public properties of the SelectedObject will be displayed in the PropertyGrid by default. You can hide a property so that it is not displayed in the PropertyGrid control by decorating it with the BrowsableAttribute and setting the value to false. You can specify the category that a property appears in by providing a category with the CategoryAttribute. You can provide descriptive text for your property that appears at the bottom of the PropertyGrid control by using the DescriptionAttribute.

Constructors

PropertyGrid()

Initializes a new instance of the PropertyGrid class.

public PropertyGrid ();

Remarks

To populate the grid, you must set the SelectedObject property.

Properties

AutoScroll

This property is not relevant for this class.

public override bool AutoScroll { get; set; }
Value
Boolean

true if enabled; otherwise, false.

Remarks

This property is not relevant for this class.

BackColor

Gets or sets the background color for the control.

public override System.Drawing.Color BackColor { get; set; }
Value
Color

A Color that represents the background color of the control. The default is the value of the stem.Windows.Forms.Control.DefaultBackColor* property.

BackgroundImage

This property is not relevant for this class.

public override System.Drawing.Image BackgroundImage { get; set; }
Value
Image

The background image of the property grid.

Remarks

This property is not relevant for this class.

BackgroundImageLayout

This property is not relevant for this class.

public override System.Windows.Forms.ImageLayout BackgroundImageLayout { get; set; }
Value
ImageLayout

The background image layout of the property grid.

Remarks

This property is not relevant for this class.

BrowsableAttributes

Gets or sets the browsable attributes associated with the object that the property grid is attached to.

public System.ComponentModel.AttributeCollection BrowsableAttributes { get; set; }
Value
AttributeCollection

The collection of browsable attributes associated with the object.

Remarks

Only properties with attributes matching the values specified are displayed in the PropertyGrid. The default is an AttributeCollection containing only System.ComponentModel.BrowsableAttribute.Yes.

Assigning an attribute collection that is empty or is null causes a new AttributeCollection to be created with System.ComponentModel.BrowsableAttribute.Yes set.

CanShowCommands

Gets a value indicating whether the commands pane can be made visible for the currently selected objects.

public virtual bool CanShowCommands { get; }
Value
Boolean

true if the commands pane can be made visible; otherwise, false.

Remarks

This property is true if CommandsVisibleIfAvailable is true and the object has commands available.

CanShowVisualStyleGlyphs

Gets or sets a value that indicates whether OS-specific visual style glyphs are used for the expansion nodes in the grid area.

public bool CanShowVisualStyleGlyphs { get; set; }
Value
Boolean

true to use the visual style glyphs; otherwise, false.

CategoryForeColor

Gets or sets the text color used for category headings.

public System.Drawing.Color CategoryForeColor { get; set; }
Value
Color

A Color structure representing the text color.

Remarks

The background color of category headings is determined by the LineColor property.

CategorySplitterColor

Gets or sets the color of the line that separates categories in the grid area.

public System.Drawing.Color CategorySplitterColor { get; set; }
Value
Color

The color of the category splitter.

CommandsActiveLinkColor

Gets or sets the color of active links in the executable commands region.

public System.Drawing.Color CommandsActiveLinkColor { get; set; }
Value
Color

A Color structure representing the active link color.

CommandsBackColor

Gets or sets the background color of the hot commands region.

public System.Drawing.Color CommandsBackColor { get; set; }
Value
Color

One of the Color values. The default is the default system color for controls.

CommandsBorderColor

Gets or sets the color of the border surrounding the hot commands region.

public System.Drawing.Color CommandsBorderColor { get; set; }
Value
Color

The color of the commands border.

CommandsDisabledLinkColor

Gets or sets the unavailable link color for the executable commands region.

public System.Drawing.Color CommandsDisabledLinkColor { get; set; }
Value
Color

A Color structure representing the unavailable link color.

CommandsForeColor

Gets or sets the foreground color for the hot commands region.

public System.Drawing.Color CommandsForeColor { get; set; }
Value
Color

One of the Color values. The default is the default system color for control text.

CommandsLinkColor

Gets or sets the link color for the executable commands region.

public System.Drawing.Color CommandsLinkColor { get; set; }
Value
Color

A Color structure representing the link color for the executable commands region.

CommandsVisible

Gets a value indicating whether the commands pane is visible.

public virtual bool CommandsVisible { get; }
Value
Boolean

true if the commands pane is visible; otherwise, false. The default is false.

Remarks

This property is true if the selected object has commands available and the CommandsVisibleIfAvailable property is true.

CommandsVisibleIfAvailable

Gets or sets a value indicating whether the commands pane is visible for objects that expose verbs.

public virtual bool CommandsVisibleIfAvailable { get; set; }
Value
Boolean

true if the commands pane is visible; otherwise, false. The default is true.

ContextMenuDefaultLocation

Gets the default location for the shortcut menu.

public System.Drawing.Point ContextMenuDefaultLocation { get; }
Value
Point

The default location for the shortcut menu if the command is invoked. Typically, this is centered over the selected property.

Remarks

The shortcut menu location is the center of the active property label in the grid. You can use this information to position the shortcut menu when the menu is invoked using the keyboard.

Controls

This property is not relevant for this class.

Value

The controls associated with the property grid.

Remarks

This property is not relevant for this class.

Size

The default Size of the control.

DefaultTabType

Gets the type of the default tab.

protected virtual Type DefaultTabType { get; }
Value
Type

A Type representing the default tab.

Remarks

The default implementation of this property returns PropertyTab. Override this property to specify a modified version of the PropertyTab.

Gets or sets the foreground color of disabled text in the grid area.

public System.Drawing.Color DisabledItemForeColor { get; set; }
Value
Color

The foreground color of disabled items.

Gets or sets a value indicating whether the PropertyGrid control paints its toolbar with flat buttons.

protected bool DrawFlatToolbar { get; set; }
Value
Boolean

true if the PropertyGrid paints its toolbar with flat buttons; otherwise false. The default is false.

ForeColor

This property is not relevant for this class.

public override System.Drawing.Color ForeColor { get; set; }
Value
Color

The foreground color of the control.

Remarks

This property is not relevant for this class.

HelpBackColor

Gets or sets the background color for the Help region.

public System.Drawing.Color HelpBackColor { get; set; }
Value
Color

One of the Color values. The default is the default system color for controls.

HelpBorderColor

Gets or sets the color of the border surrounding the description pane.

public System.Drawing.Color HelpBorderColor { get; set; }
Value
Color

The color of the help border.

HelpForeColor

Gets or sets the foreground color for the Help region.

public System.Drawing.Color HelpForeColor { get; set; }
Value
Color

One of the Color values. The default is the default system color for control text.

HelpVisible

Gets or sets a value indicating whether the Help text is visible.

public virtual bool HelpVisible { get; set; }
Value
Boolean

true if the help text is visible; otherwise, false. The default is true.

Remarks

This property enables the display of any available Help text associated with the selected property in the grid.

LargeButtons

Gets or sets a value indicating whether buttons appear in standard size or in large size.

public bool LargeButtons { get; set; }
Value
Boolean

true if buttons on the control appear large; otherwise, false. The default is false.

Remarks

You can use this property to enhance accessibility. Large buttons are 32-by-32 pixels rather than the standard 16-by-16 pixels. Both the large and small buttons are resized according to the system DPI setting when the app.config file contains the following entry: 

<appSettings>  
  <add key="EnableWindowsFormsHighDpiAutoResizing" value="true" />  
</appSettings>

LineColor

Gets or sets the color of the gridlines and borders.

public System.Drawing.Color LineColor { get; set; }
Value
Color

One of the Color values. The default is the default system color for scroll bars.

Padding

This property is not relevant for this class.

public System.Windows.Forms.Padding Padding { get; set; }
Value
Padding

A Padding value.

Remarks

This property is not relevant for this class.

PropertySort

Gets or sets the type of sorting the PropertyGrid uses to display properties.

public System.Windows.Forms.PropertySort PropertySort { get; set; }
Value
PropertySort

One of the PropertySort values. The default is PropertySort or PropertySort.

Exceptions
InvalidEnumArgumentException

The assigned value is not one of the PropertySort values.

Remarks

When you set the PropertySort property, the appearance of the property sort buttons on the grid changes to reflect the current state of the property. Setting PropertySort to System.Windows.Forms.PropertySort causes the properties to be displayed in the order they were retrieved.

Setting PropertySort to both PropertySort and PropertySort is the same as setting PropertySort to PropertySort alone. The categorized view is always shown as alphabetical.

Note

To do custom sorting, implement ICustomTypeDescriptor on the component to return the properties in the desired order.

PropertyTabs

Gets the collection of property tabs that are displayed in the grid.

public System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid.PropertyTabCollection PropertyTabs { get; }
Value

A PropertyGrid.PropertyTabCollection containing the collection of PropertyTab objects being displayed by the PropertyGrid.

Remarks

All property tabs derive from the PropertyTab class.

SelectedGridItem

Gets or sets the selected grid item.

public System.Windows.Forms.GridItem SelectedGridItem { get; set; }
Value
GridItem

The currently selected row in the property grid.

Remarks

Each GridItem corresponds to a property of the SelectedObject.

You can use the returned GridItem to view type information, the PropertyDescriptor, the parent, and the children of the selected object.

SelectedItemWithFocusBackColor

Gets or sets the background color of selected items that have the input focus.

public System.Drawing.Color SelectedItemWithFocusBackColor { get; set; }
Value
Color

The background color of focused, selected items.

SelectedItemWithFocusForeColor

Gets or sets the foreground color of selected items that have the input focus.

public System.Drawing.Color SelectedItemWithFocusForeColor { get; set; }
Value
Color

The foreground color of focused, selected items.

SelectedObject

Gets or sets the object for which the grid displays properties.

public object SelectedObject { get; set; }
Value
Object

The first object in the object list. If there is no currently selected object the return is null.

Remarks

The SelectedObject property sets a single object into the grid to be browsed. If multiple objects are being browsed, this property returns the first one in the list. If no objects are selected, null is returned.

SelectedObjects

Gets or sets the currently selected objects.

public object[] SelectedObjects { get; set; }
Value
Object[]

An array of type Object. The default is an empty array.

Exceptions
ArgumentException

One of the items in the array of objects had a null value.

Remarks

The PropertyGrid only displays the properties that are common to all the objects that are in the array. Assigning an array to the SelectedObjects replaces the reference to any SelectedObject you might make.

SelectedTab

Gets the currently selected property tab.

public System.Windows.Forms.Design.PropertyTab SelectedTab { get; }
Value
PropertyTab

The PropertyTab that is providing the selected view.

Remarks

All property tabs derive from the PropertyTab class.

ShowFocusCues

Gets a value indicating whether the control should display focus rectangles.

protected override bool ShowFocusCues { get; }
Value
Boolean

true if the control should display focus rectangles; otherwise, false.

ShowPropertyPageImage

Gets the image that represents the property page.

protected virtual System.Drawing.Bitmap ShowPropertyPageImage { get; }
Value
Bitmap

The image that represents the property page.

Site

Gets or sets the site of the control.

public override System.ComponentModel.ISite Site { get; set; }
Value
ISite

The ISite associated with the Control, if any.

SortByCategoryImage

Gets the image that represents sorting grid items by category.

protected virtual System.Drawing.Bitmap SortByCategoryImage { get; }
Value
Bitmap

The image that represents sorting by category.

SortByPropertyImage

Gets the image that represents sorting grid items by property name.

protected virtual System.Drawing.Bitmap SortByPropertyImage { get; }
Value
Bitmap

The image that represents sorting by property.

Text

Gets or sets the text associated with this control.

public override string Text { get; set; }
Value
String

The text associated with this control.

ToolbarVisible

Gets or sets a value indicating whether the toolbar is visible.

public virtual bool ToolbarVisible { get; set; }
Value
Boolean

true if the toolbar is visible; otherwise, false. The default is true.

ToolStripRenderer

Gets or sets the painting functionality for ToolStrip objects.

protected System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripRenderer ToolStripRenderer { get; set; }
Value
ToolStripRenderer

A ToolStripRenderer for the PropertyGrid.

UseCompatibleTextRendering

Gets or sets a value that determines whether to use the Graphics class (GDI+) or the TextRenderer class (GDI) to render text.

public bool UseCompatibleTextRendering { get; set; }
Value
Boolean

true if the Graphics class should be used to perform text rendering for compatibility with versions 1.0 and 1.1. of the .NET Framework; otherwise, false. The default is false.

Remarks

The UseCompatibleTextRendering property is intended to provide visual compatibility between Windows Forms controls that render text using the TextRenderer class and .NET Framework 1.0 and .NET Framework 1.1 applications that perform custom text rendering using the Graphics class. In most cases, if your application is not being upgraded from .NET Framework 1.0 or .NET Framework 1.1, it is recommended that you leave UseCompatibleTextRendering set to the default value of false.

The GDI based TextRenderer class was introduced in the .NET Framework 2.0 to improve performance, make text look better, and improve support for international fonts. In earlier versions of the .NET Framework, the GDI+ based Graphics class was used to perform all text rendering. GDI calculates character spacing and word wrapping differently from GDI+. In a Windows Forms application that uses the Graphics class to render text, this could cause the text for controls that use TextRenderer to appear different from the other text in the application. To resolve this incompatibility, you can set the UseCompatibleTextRendering property to true for a specific control. To set UseCompatibleTextRendering to true for all supported controls in the application, call the SetCompatibleTextRenderingDefault method with a parameter of true.

ViewBackColor

Gets or sets a value indicating the background color in the grid.

public System.Drawing.Color ViewBackColor { get; set; }
Value
Color

One of the Color values. The default is the default system color for windows.

ViewBorderColor

Gets or sets the color of the border surrounding the grid area.

public System.Drawing.Color ViewBorderColor { get; set; }
Value
Color

The color of the property grid border.

ViewForeColor

Gets or sets a value indicating the color of the text in the grid.

public System.Drawing.Color ViewForeColor { get; set; }
Value
Color

One of the Color values. The default is current system color for text in windows.

Methods

CollapseAllGridItems()

Collapses all the categories in the PropertyGrid.

public void CollapseAllGridItems ();

Remarks

The method collapses the categories in the grid. Those categories that have grid items in the category have a plus sign (+) displayed next to that category.

CreatePropertyTab(Type)

When overridden in a derived class, enables the creation of a PropertyTab.

protected virtual System.Windows.Forms.Design.PropertyTab CreatePropertyTab (Type tabType);
tabType
Type

The type of tab to create.

Returns
PropertyTab

The newly created property tab. Returns null in its default implementation.

Remarks

See PropertyTab for more information about creating property tabs.

Dispose(Boolean)

Disposes of the resources (other than memory) used by the PropertyGrid.

protected override void Dispose (bool disposing);
disposing
Boolean

true to release both managed and unmanaged resources; false to release only unmanaged resources.

Remarks

Call Dispose when you are finished using the PropertyGrid. The Dispose method leaves the PropertyGrid in an unusable state. After calling Dispose, you must release all references to the PropertyGrid so the memory it was occupying can be reclaimed by garbage collection.

Note

Always call Dispose before you release your last reference to the PropertyGrid. Otherwise, the resources the PropertyGrid is using will not be freed until garbage collection calls the destructor of PropertyGrid.

ExpandAllGridItems()

Expands all the categories in the PropertyGrid.

public void ExpandAllGridItems ();

OnComComponentNameChanged(ComponentRenameEventArgs)

Raises the ComComponentNameChanged event.

protected void OnComComponentNameChanged (System.ComponentModel.Design.ComponentRenameEventArgs e);
e
ComponentRenameEventArgs

A ComponentRenameEventArgs that contains the event data.

Remarks

Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate. For more information, see Events.

The OnComComponentNameChanged method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate. This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.

OnEnabledChanged(EventArgs)

Raises the EnabledChanged event.

protected override void OnEnabledChanged (EventArgs e);
e
EventArgs

An EventArgs that contains the event data.

Remarks

Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate. For more information, see Events.

The OnEnabledChanged method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate. This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.

OnFontChanged(EventArgs)

Raises the FontChanged event.

protected override void OnFontChanged (EventArgs e);
e
EventArgs

An EventArgs that contains the event data.

OnGotFocus(EventArgs)

Raises the GotFocus event.

protected override void OnGotFocus (EventArgs e);
e
EventArgs

An EventArgs that contains the event data.

Remarks

Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate. For more information, see Events.

ArgumentException

Explicit Interface Implementations

IComPropertyBrowser.DropDownDone()

Closes any open drop-down controls on the PropertyGrid control. For a description of this member, see stem.Windows.Forms.ComponentModel.Com2Interop.IComPropertyBrowser.DropDownDone*.

void IComPropertyBrowser.DropDownDone ();

Remarks

This member is an explicit interface member implementation. It can be used only when the PropertyGrid instance is cast to an IComPropertyBrowser interface.

IComPropertyBrowser.EnsurePendingChangesCommitted()

Commits all pending changes to the PropertyGrid control. For a description of this member, see stem.Windows.Forms.ComponentModel.Com2Interop.IComPropertyBrowser.EnsurePendingChangesCommitted*.

bool IComPropertyBrowser.EnsurePendingChangesCommitted ();
Returns
Boolean

true if all the PropertyGrid successfully commits changes; otherwise, false.

Remarks

This member is an explicit interface member implementation. It can be used only when the PropertyGrid instance is cast to an IComPropertyBrowser interface.

IComPropertyBrowser.HandleF4()

void IComPropertyBrowser.HandleF4 ();

Remarks

This member is an explicit interface member implementation. It can be used only when the PropertyGrid instance is cast to an IComPropertyBrowser interface.

bool System.Windows.Forms.ComponentModel.Com2Interop.IComPropertyBrowser.InPropertySet { get; }
Returns
Boolean

true if the PropertyGrid control is currently setting one of the properties of its selected object; otherwise, false.

Remarks

This member is an explicit interface member implementation. It can be used only when the PropertyGrid instance is cast to an IComPropertyBrowser interface.

IComPropertyBrowser.LoadState(RegistryKey)

Loads user states from the registry into the PropertyGrid control. For a description of this member, see stem.Windows.Forms.ComponentModel.Com2Interop.IComPropertyBrowser.LoadState*.

void IComPropertyBrowser.LoadState (Microsoft.Win32.RegistryKey optRoot);
optRoot
RegistryKey

The registry key that contains the user states.

Remarks

This member is an explicit interface member implementation. It can be used only when the PropertyGrid instance is cast to an IComPropertyBrowser interface.

Visual Studio 2005 saves some of the PropertyGrid control states, such as the PropertySort and HelpVisible properties, to the registry and loads them the next time the user runs the application.

IComPropertyBrowser.SaveState(RegistryKey)

Saves user states from the PropertyGrid control to the registry. For a description of this member, see stem.Windows.Forms.ComponentModel.Com2Interop.IComPropertyBrowser.SaveState*.

optRoot
RegistryKey

The registry key that contains the user states.

Remarks

This member is an explicit interface member implementation. It can be used only when the PropertyGrid instance is cast to an IComPropertyBrowser interface.

Visual Studio 2005 saves some of the PropertyGrid control states, such as the PropertySort and HelpVisible properties, to the registry and loads them the next time the user runs the application.
